Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2012 02:28AM MiniMacsMom wrote: Oddly enough, you can get a second opinion NOW before you start rads.  They won't change your chemo plan, but the rads team at MDA is AMAZING and their pathology department is some of the best in the world.  The path regionally at home said I had clean margins, MDA reviewed more tissue and their slides and said my margins were not clean.  I had a revision surgery and then rads at MDA.  I did 12 weekly taxol and then 4 x FAC... My MDA Onc said that protocol allows for the maximum allowable doses of chemo.  There are reasons behind why different doctors do different things.  A lot of chemo is regional.  At home I was given the "choice" of 3 regimines... TAC x6 /  DD AC + DD T / or DD AC + Tx4)   At this point, you are getting what is considered to be a normal treatment for stage 3 and their is no point in worrying about it since you can't change it.   If you do go to MDA, I used Dr. Bucholz as my RO and I LOVED him... was kinda unsure about him at my first apt, but he quickly became my favorite Dr.    Also Dr. Strom has an amazing bedside manner.  He is fun and spunky.  Didn't meet any other ROs ;)

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2012 06:30PM MiniMacsMom wrote: All the Taxol info I got from the hospitals says it can.  The more condensed your dose, the harder it will hit your WBC.  I am on the weekly taxol and I have been tracking my CBCs on a spreadsheet (gotta love a researcher ;) ) anyway, my WBCs were slowly dropping from 6.2 ku/L on week one to 5.3 on 5.  Not much of a drop.  I started taking B6 and a mutli-vitamin for preventing neuropathy and my WBC jumped to 6.9 ku/L on week 6 and its gone down a little for week 7 (only took the vitamins once last week.)   Now my doctor says CBCs like that are expected on weekly taxol because its more "gentle" than DD or Tx4 But my nurses say my CBCs are abnormally good even for weekly taxol.  Who knows. I hope your CBCs pick back up for you next treatment.  good luck and I hope you get more answers. Also take a look at your Abs neutrophils, they are the baby WBC (like the batters' on deck) growing up to take over for the WBCs, so if they are low your WBCs aren't prolly going to go back up.

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2011 09:20AM MiniMacsMom wrote: That would definately be something for her to discuss with the oncologist, its definately a scary concept of dying from the chemo, BUT she should still seek one or two or even 3 different medical opinions about her specific chances of having a reaction to the chemo.  She may not be on the same chemo as your moms' were... I am new to this, but I can definately understand how difficult it would be for her. If chemo is that scary try to get her to at least get the cancer removed.  I did, I had a single mastectomy on my right side and I was cuddling my son the day after.... and holding him on the other side within a week or so.  I am a little over three weeks out and I can now do almost everything I could before!  I just have a little more range of motion to get back.  Cancer is basically an overgrowth of cells, every single person has microscopic little cancers but its our immune systems job to step in an remove or fix the cancers.  Our bodies have many systematic redundancies to make sure these overgrowths don't happy, but when things get miswired and the redundancies don't work we get the microscopic cancers.   When the immune system malfunctions our cancers get out of control.  I have lived a very holistic low chemical green lifestyle for almost 3 years now and it did not prevent my cancer from getting out of control.   We eat organic, use all VOC free products ect.... and I still had a 9x6x5cm tumor stage 3 agressice with 5lymphs involved ;) Goodluck with whatever happens, I will send good mojo your way ;)  Again,

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2013 06:10AM MiniMacsMom wrote: Kelly, I definately found that there are some consequences with the little one.  They may not seem noticable to others but are definate to me.  Some I love and some not so much.  For instance, he is SOOO compasionate.  When a baby is crying in the store he wants to make sure its ok.  When mommy gets an ouchie, he wants to kiss it and give me hugs.  More so than some other kids I have seen.  On the down side he tends to be more moodie.  For instance we went to TX for 3 days for my check up and my mom came to stay with him.  He had fun with my mom but he has been cranky and clingy since I got back.  Its been a few months since momma disapeared so I think he was getting used to his new normal.  We had prepared him for us to leave but when we would call he would hang up on us.  Its normal from hwat I understand, but annoying.  When I had my first surgery he was 15 mo I could only let him sit on my lap at first, no holding.  Then gradually moved up to holding after about 2 weeks, with approval.  I had help with my first surgery, my second I didnt.  So we tried to prepare in advance.  He was around 22 mo for the second surgery so we deconstructed his crib and put the mattress on the floor with the toddler rail up.  He has done really well with that.  I wasn't able to lift him for 2 weeks, but I was on my own, so we improvised.  We got lots of stools so he could climb in his chair easier and wash his hand.  It really helped.  D is super cuddly but also very self sufficient.  When I was on chemo and really sick and alone I would "talk" him through how to get to things. So he is really great at figuring stuff out.  You do what you have to do to get through it.  Will there be issues he has to deal with, YUP but I was told by a child therapist that as long as they are loved and surrounded by love nothing that happens is insurmountable.  Other quirks are my hair, he didn't care about my hair when I had long hair but after being bald and now with short hair he loves to run his hands through it.  Mostly just a bunch of little things.  But he is also 2.5 now so a huge part of the problem is his age as well now ;)  It sucks and their are no guidebooks for kids this age, just do what feels right for your family!  At first we just said mommy had an ouchie boobie, now we are starting to define it more as mommy has a cancer boobie.  We were told that around to they start to need to know the difference in ouchies or they will think they have to have surgery if they get a small cut :(  it helps to define the severity of ouchies.  Its weird but he does seem to understand.  And when other little kids ask I always make sure to say I have a cancer ouchie but its not contagious.  Gotta love the little things!  Sorry, its alot of info, but we have learned a lot on this whole journey.  :)

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2012 07:58PM MiniMacsMom wrote: Its not an easy thing to do, but you have to do whats best for YOU.  For some that means not telling anyone, for others it means sharing everything with everyone all the time ;)  For me, I called a select group of friends and family and (maybe 10 people) and then to all the satelite friends and family I wanted to tell my hubby and I drafted a email.  We didn't want second hand info getting to people so we put in everything that we considered pertinent.  We then set up a Caringbridge account, that way we didnt' clog people's emails all the time for people to get updates.  For me it was less invasive.  People knew they were getting direct correct info as it was available and we weren't bombarded with questions ALL the time.   :)  They also now have a care calendar where people can sign up to help you if you need it, for food or house cleaning, lawn mowing, rides whatever/whenever you need it.  I also love that its password protected and you get total control over who sees your page.  For me though, mainly it was to keep people informed properly.  I didn't want any "telephone chains"  ending up where I am at deaths door...  It worked well for me but everyone has their own method.  Mainly you need to focus on YOU, whats easiest for you right now and what makes you happy.  These next few weeks are usually the hardest and most uncertain so minimizing your stress level is Key!

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2012 09:34PM MiniMacsMom wrote: I could be wrong but I "think" I remembered a journal art reposted on the forums a while back that said that fasting the day of may increase the effectiveness of chemo.  Please don't jump me, I could very well be wrong.  I personally wouldn't fast a ton, the weaker you body is the harder it will be to fight things off.  My docs pushed eating as much protein as possible to help speed healing.  I just found out that one serving of good chicken stock contains 5 g of protein and is pretty easy to keep down!   I ended up with the 72 hr nausea, I was mostly fine the first two days on FAC, but at the 2.5-3 day mark I got crazy sick.  My MO started giving me IV emend on treatment day.  If you do the IV emend on treatment it works on the 72 hour nausea much better than zofran and the other pills, plus the insurance will pay for it if its givin iv at the hospital or infusion center.  At least thats what my MO said/did and the insurance did pay for it.  It really helped me get through that tough spot.  In the end, just keep up good communication with your doc, and they can help keep you on meds to help with side effects.  I also remember articles I think on the effects of various relaxation techniques during treatments.  So I would google the chemo and yoga ect... they might help.  Good luck, I did a different chemo overall, but I made it through even though there were some  times I didn't think I would and during the every 3 week chemo, weeks 2 and 3 I felt well and was able to be active.

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2011 02:05PM MiniMacsMom wrote: Pet scans carry an added risk due to the radioactive dye that is injected into you.  CT, MRI, Ultrasounds, and Mammograms carry less risk and are less expensive than PET scans.  If your biopsy comes back positive then you may still get a PET scan at some point but its not routine unless youhave a positive biopsy.  If you are not comfortable with your doctors or worried that they missed something, request copies of all of your scans (they may be on DVD) and make an appt with an NCI (National Cancer Institue) accredited center.  most NCI centers will have breast cancer specialists that are experts in their field!  They will be much less likely to miss something.  Good luck and I hope everything comes back normal for you!

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2012 01:35PM MiniMacsMom wrote: I am on the weekly taxol and I think its great. I am tired and cranky, but otherwise no other side effects.  I see a chiropractor now and the minor neuropathy like symptoms were just pinched nerves :)  I also take (though not with good regularity)  B6, L Glutamine and Acetyl L Carnatine.  I started this last week after treatment 5 and my CBC labs were up this week!!  I have more baby WBC now than I did pre chemo!!!  I have heard a lot of different opinions on the effectiveness of weeky vs  bi weekly.  I think both are superior to the 1 every 3 weeks, but  I don't think there is a diffinative answer otherwise on which has a better effect on progosis.   I know that going into the winter, with a little one and germies I needed the treatment that would be the kindest to my immune system.  Dr. Alvarez at MDA didn't give me the option for every 2 weeks, but I am really happy with the weekly treatments overall.  I still even have some of my hair on my head and all my other hair.  tmetz: interesting to hear it starts to grow after the 6th treatment, I will be looking forward to it!  I think its important to take into account your likely hood to get sick from germs on the treatments.  If there is a high chance of illness, the weekly is better because they will delay your bi-weekly chemo if you get the flu or something, which would reduce the overall effectiveness.  Good luck!

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2012 03:36AM MiniMacsMom wrote: There is great advice on the LE tread about lymphedema.  Basically when you get an injury to the at risk arm you want to rest, drink lots of water, take deep breaths through out the day, breath as full as your stomach can get and then let air out and compress your stomach as small as it can get, it stimulates the Lymphs in the stomach area, which is your largest concentration of lymphs... When your LE are is compromised and you get an injury, your body brings fluid to the arm to treat the injury and may not be able to get the fluid to leave. its harder to get it out.  When there is fluid buildup you increase your risk of cellulitus, a PTA infection... When doing rads or chemo any infection needed antibiotics will slow your treatment.  So they say minimize risk as much as possible.  Wear gloves and long sleeves hwen gardening, gloves when dishwashing, bug spray, no sunburn, ect.  I am only 28 with NO lymphs on my right side PLUS rads, so lymphedema is part o my new normal :(  But my arm looks normal with some work that we are doing, and over time, hopefully, I can decerase the amount of time it takes to keep the LE under control.  Sorry for the rant ;)

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2011 01:11PM MiniMacsMom wrote: Statistically speaking your risk is low.  I believe it is something like 80% of masses are nothing, BUT there is a growing fraction of us young pregnant or post pregnancy women who are getting breast cancer.  I absolutely do not want to scare you, but it is in your best interest/piece of mind for you to get this checked out.  It is also possible for a biopsy to be negative if they "missed the tumor".  The most sensitive test for breast cancer (as I was told) is an MRI,  it will light up on a lot of benign things though, so if you get one be prepared for more biopsies.  But again, especially with what has already come back negative and with statistics on your side we should be able to hope that its nothing confidently.  I hate these "safety" claused but its hard to give a definate yes or no!  The best thing I can recommend is get copies.  Get photocopies of your path reports and your doctors notes.  Get copies of your ultrasound and biopsy scans, so if something (god forbid) does happen in the future, you know where you started and when you were clean.  ;)  Best of luck and I hope you don't have to join our family!!! I am a newbie and as much as I love the support, I would rather be sleeping or playing with my son than trolling forums for answers and support!

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2011 04:34PM MiniMacsMom wrote: I thought the same thing, before find out my BRCA status.  But there are many cons to being ovary free that you have to be prepared for.  There is the obvious menopausal state and the hot flashes and such... but also the significantly increased risk of hear diseas and bone loss as well as many other.  They say all things considered, ovary removal early can significantly lower your lifespan, though when going through treatment a 10 year decrease from 80 years doesn't seem like a whole lot when the average survival for stage 111 BC may not get us to the 70 to begin with depending on your age.  If you search there are a few threads dedicated to pros and cons of ovary removal earlly.  Good luck, its definately a hard decision to make.

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2011 04:37PM MiniMacsMom wrote: I was in your shoes "a few weeks ago, and it gets both easier and harder.  I had my Mastectomy (rt side also) on 11.3!  At this point, I know the pathology of my cancer and what treatments I get.  My uncle who is a Dr. Said it best, He said " Oh Shit girl, strap on your boxing gloves and be prepared for one hell of a fight"  Despite the fact that "failure is not an option" is now our family motto, you will get scare, and angry and up set.  Its not all sunshite and positive attitude all the time.  Greive, feel the emotions, talk at home, talk on the forums, start a family blog... There are alot ofthings to do.  I started a blog on caringbridge.org thats private but I can update my family :)  I don't have to call everyone or wait for things to get distorted in the food chain, they can check on us without being invasive and leave little notes of encouragement.  It helps.  I am not sensored on the blog, tell people how you feel.   Its ok to be terrified. No one wants to leave their kids... I say this and earlier today I was crying during a cat scan praying for no mets...  Everyone on here is here to support you, I have learned that much in two weeks!  Sending you all the best wishes from our home!

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2011 07:33PM MiniMacsMom wrote: So, I have my own update for people.  I guess it's called "fertility preservation"!  Fertile Hope in conjunction with livestrong will send you one courses worth of 4 specific types of fertility drugs if you qualify.  AND some doctors will give discounted rates.  The process with livestrong is very fast, as long as you have the paperwork in, it can get approved the same day and the drugs sent same day or next day.  This can be a savings of up to $4500!  Our reproductive endocrinologist actually told us about this.  It doesn't cover anything but these 4 specific meds, but thats still a HUGE savings.  The patient paperwork is easy, the biggest qualification is income limits and for a couple you have to be less than $100K.    The oncologist and fertility doctor paperwork is also a page or so!!! I am sure this is posted somewhere else, but... it helps.   At 27 my husband and I had to bring this up and INSIST we are given the option of finding someone to help us.  The surgeon was going to just send us to chemo 3 weeks after surgery and we could be screwed in the end....  The fert specialist says we can have this done in 2.5 weeks since I am not infertile now and I don't need all the extra time to follow a normal cycle!!  There is HOPE!

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 07:38PM MiniMacsMom wrote: They should get you in fast.  They called me on Tues and wanted me there Friday but I didn't have my drains out :)  Also, with UHC, our has a cancer service to call for help and advice.  They told me about a program where they re-imburse you up to 10K in travel expenses to one of 22 "Cancer care of excellence" centers in the us as long as you are 30 mi or more away for one.  It covers mileage, flight and housing costs.  I am not sure about your plan, but it wouldn't hurt to call.  I also have a Myuhc account and I can check my insurance billing live.  Wth MDA It was all covered snce I was n my out of pocket but MDA billed one insurance code wrong.  I got a $500 bll and had to call them and have them re-bill it :)  It was pretty simple.  Since all the doctors work for MDA you should only get one bill.  Its pretty awsome compared to getting like 8 different bills for my MX.  I think they pathology for the biopsy was only like 200 and the BC tumor path was like 800.  Hope it helps.

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2012 03:20AM MiniMacsMom wrote: In terms of heart damage, my tumor was on my right side, but i am getting treatment to my breastbone are.  On that area, the MDA docs use electrons instead of photons because they degrade at a much lower distance.  They shoot the photons at an angle across my whole breast and then localize electrons to the breast bone.  The boosts to my breastbone, superclav, scar and arpit (seems like almost the whole thing :) ) will also be straight on with electrons.  I am not sure how common this is for centers to use, but my RO says its what helps to midigate the damage to the internal organs.  Big HUGS! I started in June but I will continue my rads all they way til July. :)

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2013 09:51PM MiniMacsMom wrote: I had chemo surgery and rads. Mine were normal looking at 1 month after rads... 3 no after chemo. But the no said there are still microscopic systems that they can't test for that still qualified me for immune compromised at that point. I'm a year out of chemo and still measuring normal. But the barometer is hard. I am under 30. Otherwise healthy and I try to eat well. I really hope u feel better soon. Oh I had taxol weekly and then FAC. I got two neulasta shots 3 weeks after my last chemo... when my ABC tanked for the first time. go figure.

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2011 06:21PM MiniMacsMom wrote: I think the best thing is to have confidence and acceptance.  By that I mean accepting what you have been given with this illness so that you are ready to fight and confidence in your medical team.  I was a hot mess until I got a second opinion at the best cancer treatment facility in the country.  I was thinking that I only had to live for the short term before hand, why put my body and famil through all the stress if I was goign to die anyway.  Then I got a new medical team.  I still get cranky but I am so confident in my medical team that I truely don't have those death and dying thoughts anymore.  Its weird, but I am planning for the long term again.  Seeing my son graduate college, ect and he is 17 mo old.  I am even (gasp) thinking of having more kids in a few years once this is all over and originally I thought it was hopeless.  :)  I hope you find something that works for you to keep those deep dark thoughts at bay, but I truely believe that stage 3 isn't the end of the world, and if things do stay the same or progress that there will be new/amazing treatments in a few years that will work wonders!
